comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I'm a kind of a city fella but I always thought swedes were blonde???  Seriously I thought that swedes were smaller and whiter than these.  Apparently these were rarely used for human consumption until WW1, they were used to feed animals until then.  When I was growing up they were referred to as Mangols!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Well, some of this series of photos are described as Swedish Turnips which I think was the photographer hedging his bets!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: My instinct is swede, but then according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rutabaga whilst known as swede in most British English speaking countries, this is known as turnip in Ireland!!! And then according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turnip "The leaves grow directly from the above-ground shoulder of the root, with little or no visible crown or neck (as found in rutabagas)" [rutabaga=swede - see link above!]. This seems to again make these swedes (in the British English sense, but not the Irish sense!) as the ones shown here DO have a neck I feel.

comment.author: 22562862@N06
comment._content:
They look like swedes - turnips are much smaller and flatter. Swedes have orange flesh, turnips white. 

Just to confuse matters, swedes were known as turnips where I grew up in Yorkshire (1950s) and they're called neeps in Scotland.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: So far, the Swedes seem to have it! And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/22562862@N06] isn't there a traditional dish in Scotland that's "something and neeps" or "neeps and something", just like bacon and cabbage here?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Yorkshire folk are the salt of the earth and if they say they're turnips then turnips they are!  It seems to be a case of where you are that decides if they are white or peach.  I think it's either Haggis or Tatties and neeps in Scotland.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Checked, and it is tatties and neeps that are served with haggis...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: Nice Classic Photo. Nice Place. The Turnips were very well organized to view.

comment._content: they look like dirty bombs.

comment.author: 54690684@N07
comment._content: The term "turnip" is sort of a general term that can refer to several related vegetables.  Where I am (US) "turnip" normally means the small  white and purple root vegetable.  Those are also called "purple turnips."  The vegetable in this picture is normally called a rutabaga in the US, but sometimes called "yellow turnip."  In other countries it's called swede.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54690684@N07] Think swedes are edging ahead in this very scientifically conducted Flickr poll!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: They certainly look like what we called swedes when I was a child in New Zealand - the same veg as neeps here in Scotland. And yes, bashed neeps and tatties are eaten with haggis.
